title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #862: Maximal Sidon Subsets**

Let A₁(N) = number of maximal Sidon subsets of {1,...,N}.

Two questions:
1. Is A₁(N) < 2^{o(N^{1/2})}?
2. Is A₁(N) > 2^{N^c} for some c > 0?

**Answers:**
- Q1: NO (the lower bound refutes this)
- Q2: YES, with A₁(N) ≥ 2^{(0.16+o(1))√N}

**Status:** SOLVED (Saxton-Thomason, 2015)
mathContext: A Sidon set is where all pairwise sums are distinct. Maximal means no element can be added while preserving this property.

title: Sidon Set Definition
Maximal Sidon Set
content:
**IsMaximalSidonSet N S:**

1. S is a Sidon subset of {1,...,N}
2. No element of {1,...,N}\S can be added while keeping Sidon property

Every Sidon set is contained in some maximal Sidon set.

title: Counting Functions
Largest Sidon Set Size
content:
**f(N):** Maximum size of Sidon subset of {1,...,N}

**Classical result:** f(N) ~ √N

More precisely: (1 - ε)√N ≤ f(N) ≤ (1 + ε)√N for large N.

Proved using constructions from finite projective planes.

title: Cameron-Erdős Questions
content:
**Question 1:** Is A₁(N) < 2^{o(N^{1/2})}?

(Is the growth subexponential in √N?)

**Question 2:** Is A₁(N) > 2^{N^c} for some c > 0?

(Is there a polynomial lower bound in the exponent?)

title: Saxton-Thomason Lower Bound
content:
**saxton_thomason_lower_bound:**

A(N) ≥ 2^{(1.16+o(1))√N}

The number of all Sidon sets is at least exponential in √N with constant 1.16.

This is the key ingredient from their 2015 paper using hypergraph containers.

title: Subsets per Maximal
content:
**maximal_sidon_subsets_bound:**

Each maximal Sidon set M has ≤ 2^{(1+o(1))√N} Sidon subsets.

Since |M| ≤ (1+o(1))√N, the number of subsets is at most 2^{|M|} ≤ 2^{(1+o(1))√N}.

title: Main Theorem
Question 2: YES
content:
**question2_positive:** CameronErdosQuestion2

YES, A₁(N) > 2^{N^c} for c ≈ 0.1.

Since √N > N^{0.1} for large N, the bound 2^{0.16√N} gives the answer.

title: Question 1: NO
content:
**question1_negative:** ¬CameronErdosQuestion1

NO, A₁(N) is NOT < 2^{o(√N)}.

The lower bound A₁(N) ≥ 2^{0.16√N} shows A₁(N) grows at least as fast as 2^{c√N} for c = 0.16.

title: Hypergraph Container Method
content:
**container_method & sidon_as_independent_set:**

Key technique from Saxton-Thomason (2015).

**Idea:**
1. View Sidon sets as independent sets in hypergraph H
2. H has vertex set {1,...,N}, edges {a,b,c,d} where a+b=c+d
3. Container lemma: all independent sets lie in few 'containers'
4. Count containers to bound number of Sidon sets

title: Connection to Problem 861
content:
**problem_861_bounds & connection_861_862:**

Problem 861 asks about A(N), all Sidon sets.

**Bounds:**
- Lower: A(N) ≥ 2^{1.16·f(N)} (Saxton-Thomason)
- Upper: A(N) ≤ 2^{6.442·f(N)} (Kohayakawa et al.)

The problems are tightly connected via the subset relationship.

title: B_h Sequences
content:
**IsBhSet h S:** Generalizes Sidon sets to h-wise sums.

All h-tuples with the same sum must be identical (as multisets).

Sidon sets = B₂ sets. Counting maximal B_h sets for h > 2 remains open.
